items.text: Right now I feel completely wired and full of energy.
items.rationale: Directly describes a state of high physiological and psychological activation, the core of the arousal dimension.

items.text: My heart is racing and my mind is going a mile a minute.
items.rationale: Describes somatic and cognitive indicators of high arousal without specifying positive or negative valence.

items.text: I feel sluggish and barely have the energy to move.
items.rationale: Captures the low end of the arousal dimension — deactivation and lethargy — without clear valence.

items.text: I am so keyed up right now that I can't sit still.
items.rationale: Restlessness and inability to remain still are hallmark indicators of high arousal.

items.text: I feel drowsy and on the verge of falling asleep.
items.rationale: Drowsiness is a prototypical marker of low arousal/deactivation in the circumplex.

items.text: Everything around me feels intensely vivid and stimulating.
items.rationale: Heightened perceptual sensitivity reflects a state of high activation on the arousal axis.

items.text: I feel completely still inside, as if everything has slowed down.
items.rationale: Internal stillness and perceived slowing of time indicate low arousal without specifying pleasantness.

items.text: My muscles are tense and I feel on high alert.
items.rationale: Muscle tension and hypervigilance are somatic markers of high physiological arousal.

items.text: I feel wide awake and mentally sharp right now.
items.rationale: Wakefulness and cognitive sharpness are direct indicators of activated arousal.

items.text: I can barely keep my eyes open; my body feels heavy.
items.rationale: Physical heaviness and difficulty staying awake are classic low-arousal descriptors.

items.text: I feel a surge of adrenaline coursing through me.
items.rationale: Adrenaline surge is a prototypical high-arousal physiological experience, valence-neutral.

items.text: I'm in a dull, foggy state where nothing really registers.
items.rationale: Cognitive fog and dullness reflect deactivation on the arousal dimension.

items.text: I feel stirred up inside but I couldn't tell you whether it's good or bad.
items.rationale: Clearly describes activation, but the explicit mention of ambiguous valence introduces slight conceptual overlap.

items.text: I feel numb and completely flat, like nothing could move me.
items.rationale: Numbness and flatness suggest low arousal, but emotional flatness could also indicate low negative valence (displeasure).

items.text: I'm so excited I feel like I could burst — everything is amazing right now.
items.rationale: High excitement maps to high arousal, but 'everything is amazing' introduces strong positive valence, placing this in the high-arousal/high-valence quadrant.

items.text: I feel genuinely happy and at peace with how things are going.
items.rationale: Happiness and peace directly capture the pleasant end of the valence dimension.

items.text: There is a deep sense of satisfaction in my life right now.
items.rationale: Satisfaction is a core marker of positive valence without implying high or low arousal.

items.text: I feel miserable and nothing seems to bring me any pleasure.
items.rationale: Misery and anhedonia are prototypical markers of the unpleasant pole of valence.

items.text: Everything feels warm and good — I'm in a really positive mood.
items.rationale: Warmth and positive mood are direct descriptors of high pleasant valence.

items.text: I feel a persistent sense of displeasure that I can't shake.
items.rationale: Persistent displeasure is a clear marker of negative valence without specifying arousal level.

items.text: Life feels rewarding and I'm grateful for what I have.
items.rationale: Feelings of reward and gratitude are hallmarks of positive affective valence.

items.text: I feel content and comfortable in this moment.
items.rationale: Contentment and comfort are prototypical pleasant, moderate-arousal valence descriptors.

items.text: There's an unpleasant heaviness in my chest, like something is wrong.
items.rationale: Unpleasant somatic sensation with a sense that something is wrong captures negative valence.

items.text: I feel cheerful and lighthearted today.
items.rationale: Cheerfulness and lightheartedness are direct positive valence descriptors.

items.text: Everything seems bleak and joyless to me right now.
items.rationale: Bleakness and joylessness are clear indicators of the unpleasant pole of valence.

items.text: I feel a quiet sense of well-being that I can't quite explain.
items.rationale: Well-being is a core positive valence experience; 'quiet' keeps arousal neutral.

items.text: I feel like the world is a hostile, unpleasant place.
items.rationale: Perceiving the world as hostile and unpleasant directly taps negative valence.

items.text: I feel okay — not great, not terrible, just somewhere in the middle.
items.rationale: Describes a neutral midpoint on valence, which is informative but may be less discriminating at scale.

items.text: I feel a vague sense of unease, though I'm not sure why.
items.rationale: Unease is mildly unpleasant (negative valence), but its vagueness could also reflect mild arousal or anxiety.

items.text: I feel deeply sad and I can't stop crying — my whole body is shaking.
items.rationale: Deep sadness is clearly negative valence, but crying and body shaking introduce strong high-arousal activation, placing this at the boundary of both dimensions.
